last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18660219
>adding things after other things is hard : (
The female mind at work.

>>18660218
Sure is. Just add long cooking ones first, then medium cooking ones after and short cooking ones last, ezpz. The bigger issue is mixing ones with complementing textures. For example, acini di pepe don't go well with ditalini or conchiglette because they will get stuck in the ditalini's holes or the conchigliette's concave shapes. Better to mix either of those two with a broken long pasta (linguine, for example) and a medium pasta (like gemelli)

last_replies.com: Anyone got a good recipe for this shit?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18659827
2 c. sugar
1/2 c. light corn syrup
6 Tbsp. butter, unsalted
1/2 tsp. baking soda
1 1/2 c. dry-roasted peanuts, salted

Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil or parchment and grease with butter
Combine sugar, corn syrup and 1/2 cup water in a saucepan
Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, boil until golden brown and mixture reaches 340 degrees F, about 15 minutes
Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the butter and baking soda until smooth (bubbles/foam will form)
Stir in peanuts
Pour mixture onto the prepared baking sheet and spread into a thin, even layer
Allow mixture to harden, uncovered, at room temperature until cooled completely
Break into pieces, store in an airtight container

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: People say that coffee tastes better when you grind it just before brewing rather than purchasing it pre-ground. But if you have one of these Chinese drip-brewers like I do, does it really matter? I bought whole bean and pre-ground varieties of the same brand of coffee and they taste the same. There is no way I'm buying a more expensive coffee maker so I'm considering switching entirely to pre-ground for convenience's sake.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18659945
It has to do with freshness. Stale coffee tastes bad compared to freshly roasted coffee. Fresh coffee tastes optimal 2-3 days to a month after roasting. Coffee goes stale through oxidation, as in contact with air. The organic volatile compounds that make coffee taste nice are irreversibly lost in contact with air over time. Ground coffee has a much greater surface area to volume, thus it goes stale more quickly. The reasons both whole bean and pre-ground coffees taste the same is that they were either both very fresh, or both very old and stale, but the pre-ground coffee will always go stale faster then whole coffee beans.
